question: Transition Level refers to what altitude reference?

choices.choice: Is published for the aerodrome in the Section ENR of the AIP
Shall be the lowest flight level available for use above the transition altitude
Is calculated and declared for an approach by the Pilot-in command

subject: Regulations
explanation:
• Transition Level (TL) is the lowest flight level available for use above the Transition Altitude (TA).
  • The Transition Altitude is the altitude at or below which vertical positioning is referenced to altitude (QNH), and above which it is referenced to flight levels (QNE).
  • The Transition Level is calculated based on the atmospheric pressure and is usually published in the Aeronautical Information Publication (AIP) of each country.

question: How is transition between altitude and flight level carried out?

choices.choice: At transition level during climb and transition altitude during descent
At transition altitude during climb and transition level during descent

subject: Regulations
explanation:
The transition altitude is the altitude above which aircraft switch from using altitude (measured in feet) to flight levels (measured in hundreds of feet) based on standard pressure settings (SPS). Below the transition altitude, pilots set their altimeters to the local QNH, which provides the actual altitude above sea level. Once above the transition altitude, they set their altimeters to the standard pressure setting of 1013.25 hPa (29.92 inHg), and their altitude is then reported in flight levels (FL).

\n

subject: Regulations
explanation:

  • Distress (Emergency): 7700

  • Communication failure: 7600

choices.choice: Vertical position with reference to MSL
Vertical position with reference to aerodrome elevation
Vertical position with reference to touchdown

question: When choosing a flight level for a flight, the following factors must be considered: 1. Ensuring sufficient terrain clearance. 2 Compliance with ATC requirements, including danger or restricted areas. 3 Maintaining the required minimum traffic separation. 4 Providing adequate spacing from VFR traffic by applying differential flight levels. 5 Selecting a level that aligns with the prescribed table of cruising/flight levels.
subject: Regulations
explanation:
• Terrain clearance ensures the aircraft is safely above obstacles like mountains or high terrain.
  • ATC requirements must be followed, avoiding restricted areas such as Danger or Prohibited Airspace.
  • Traffic separation is maintained by selecting a flight level that prevents mid-air collisions.
  • VFR traffic separation requires applying differential flight levels to keep safe distance from VFR flights.
  • Cruising level tables guide flight level selection based on direction of travel (eastbound/westbound).

question: Minimum climb gradient required for a missed approach is what percent?
subject: Regulations
explanation:
The design of the missed approach consists of the three phases:

  • Initial
  • Intermediate
  • Final
  • The nominal missed approach climb gradient is 2.5%. Gradients of 3%, 4% or 5% may be used for aircraft of which the climb performance permits an operational advantage to be thus obtained and this is indicated on the instrument approach chart.

question: If an aircraft has Mode C, what must the pilot do with it?

choices.choice: Shall continuously operate this mode only when the aircraft is within controlled airspace
Shall continuously operate this mode regardless of ATC instructions
Shall continuously operate this mode unless otherwise directed by ATC

subject: Regulations
explanation:
Mode Charlie encodes and transmits the aircraft’s altitude relative to the Standard Pressure Setting (SPS) of 1013 hPa. Whenever the transponder is in use, Mode Charlie should be selected to ensure that altitude information is continuously transmitted to air traffic control.

question: ATC provides QNH at what point in a flight?
subject: Regulations
explanation:
1. The QNH should be provided to the aircraft in the taxi clearance prior to takeoff.
  2. When flying below the transition altitude, the aircraft’s vertical position is reported as altitude (with QNH set on the altimeter).

question: The phase of flight below 1000 ft DH/MDH is called what?
subject: Regulations
explanation:
Approach to Landing means that portion of the flight of the aircraft, when approaching to land, in which it is descending below a height of 1000 ft above the relevant specified decision height or minimum descent height.

question: The design of instrument departures is dictated by what main factor?
subject: Regulations
explanation:
• Instrument departure procedures assume that all engines are operating normally.
  • The design of these procedures is primarily dictated by the terrain surrounding the aerodrome.
  • Procedures may also be tailored to accommodate ATC requirements, including adjacent ATS routes.
  • Considerations include restricted, prohibited, or danger areas, as well as the proximity of other aerodromes.

question: Obstacle clearance for ILS assumes what maximum deviation from centerline?

choices.choice: half scale deflection of the localizer indicator
full scale deflection of the localizer indicator
half scale deflection of the glidepath indicator and horizontal 35° off the centreline

subject: Regulations
explanation:
• A precision approach provides accurate track guidance (azimuth) and height information (elevation) during the final approach segment.
  • External equipment (e.g., ILS or GLS) is required to supply this data.
  • The aircraft must follow the required track and glide path with an accuracy of half scale deflection on the course deviation indicator (CDI).
  • This ensures the aircraft stays within a protected area, providing terrain clearance above the Obstacle Clearance Altitude/Height (OCA/H) throughout the procedure.

question: Descent or climb in a holding pattern is known as what?
subject: Regulations
explanation:
• Shuttle maneuver is used for controlled climbing or descending within the structure of a holding pattern.
  • The aircraft maintains the usual track along the inbound or outbound legs during the maneuver.
  • Speed and timing adjustments are essential to ensure that the aircraft remains within the parameters of the hold while safely reaching the desired altitude.

question: Which factors are used to calculate DA/DH?

choices.choice: The OCA/H based on the highest obstacle in the final approach path only, plus a margin for height loss on any go around
The OCA/H based on the highest obstacle in the missed approach path only, plus am allowance for height loss on any go around
The OCA/H based on the highest obstacle in the approach or missed approach paths including an allowance for aircraft speed and height loss on any go around, plus a margin for operational factors

subject: Regulations
explanation:
The OCA/H based on the highest obstacle in the approach or missed approach paths including an allowance for aircraft speed and height loss on any go-around, plus a margin for operational factors.

This approach ensures that all potential obstacles are taken into account, providing a safe margin for the aircraft during both the approach and the missed approach phases.

question: How much obstacle clearance is required in the intermediate segment of an approach?
subject: Regulations
explanation:
INTERMEDIATE APPROACH SEGMENT
This is the segment during which the aircraft speed and configuration should be adjusted to prepare the aircraft for final approach. For this reason, the descent gradient is kept as shallow as possible.
Minimum Obstacle Clearance
During the intermediate approach, the obstacle clearance requirement reduces from 300 m (984 ft) to 150 m (492 ft) in the primary area, reducing laterally to zero at the outer edge of the secondary area.

question: Which area is primary during intermediate approach?

choices.choice: 3/4 of the total width of the airspace used to determine the minimum obstacle clearance for the approach
1/2 of the total width of the airspace used to determine the minimum obstacle clearance for the approach
10 NM either side of the approach path

subject: Regulations
explanation:
1/2 of the total width of the airspace used to determine the minimum obstacle clearance for the approach.

\n

This primary area guarantees full obstacle clearance, with the lateral dimensions gradually tapering as they extend outward into the secondary area, where reduced obstacle clearance may apply.

question: In the transition layer, how is vertical position expressed?

choices.choice: Altitude above mean sea level during climb.
Either altitude above mean sea level or flight level during climb
Altitude above mean sea level during descent

subject: Regulations
explanation:
• Transition Layer is the airspace between the Transition Altitude (TA) (altitude referenced to QNH) and the Transition Level (TL) (flight level referenced to standard pressure setting SPS or 1013.25 hPa).
  • Ascending through the Transition Layer:
    • Vertical position is reported in flight levels (FL) using SPS (Standard Pressure Setting).
  • Descending through the Transition Layer:
    • Vertical position is reported in altitude using QNH (local pressure).

question: In omni-directional departures, what altitude must be reached before turning?
subject: Regulations
explanation:
• In the absence of defined track guidance, the omni-directional method allows initial departure tracks to be undefined, permitting navigation in any direction once off the runway.
  • Pilots must be aware of obstacles in certain sectors, which may restrict departures; published procedures will indicate these restricted sectors.
  • The basic procedure requires the aircraft to climb on the extended runway centerline to 120 m (394 ft) above aerodrome elevation before making any turns.
  • At least 90 m (295 ft) of obstacle clearance must be achieved before turns greater than 15° can be specified.

question: A SID terminates at what point?

point 15 nms from DER on departure leg.

question: Minimum sector altitudes are established for how many NM from IAF?
subject: Regulations
explanation:
Minimum Sector Altitudes (MSA) and Terminal Arrival Altitudes (TAA):

  1. MSA/TAA are established for each aerodrome to ensure safe obstacle clearance.
  2. They provide a minimum of 300 m (984 ft) of obstacle clearance.
  3. This clearance is maintained within 25 NM of the navigation aid, Initial Approach Fix (IAF), or Intermediate Fix (IF) associated with the approach procedures.

question: In offset racetrack entry, time on offset leg is limited to how long?
subject: Regulations
explanation:
In PANS-OPS, the offset entry is typically discussed in the context of racetrack patterns and holds, where a 30° offset track may be flown for 1 minute 30 seconds as part of the standard entry technique. This timing allows the aircraft to fly the appropriate lateral distance before turning to rejoin the inbound track.

question: With a transponder installed, when must it be operated?

choices.choice: At all times during flight, regardless of whether the aircraft is within or outside airspace where SSR is used for ATS purposes
Only when the aircraft is flying within controlled airspace
Only when the aircraft is flying within airspace where SSR is used for ATS purposes

question: If SSR transponder is inoperative before flight, what is required?

choices.choice: A flight to be closest airport, where a repair can be made is allowed
A flight can not be made
It is necessary to specify this failure in the appropriate field of the flight plan

    • Enter ‘N’ in item 10 of the FP form.
    • Follow published procedures for seeking exemption from mandatory transponder carriage.
    • If required, proceed to the nearest suitable aerodrome for transponder repair.

question: You are on an IFR flight executing a circling approach. A descend below the MDA should not be made until: 1. the pilot has the landing threshold in sight 2. visual reference has been established and can be maintained 3. the required obstacle clearance can be maintained and a landing can be made The combination regrouping all the correct statements is:
subject: Regulations
explanation:
A descent below the Minimum Descent Altitude (MDA) during a circling approach should not be made until:

  1. The landing threshold or other required visual reference (e.g., runway lights, approach lighting) is in sight.
  2. Visual reference has been established and can be maintained, ensuring continuous visibility of the runway environment.
  3. The required obstacle clearance can be maintained, and the pilot is in a position to execute a safe landing.

question: The circling maneuver after instrument approach to align for landing is called what?
subject: Regulations
explanation:
Visual Manoeuvring (Circling) (VM(C)):

  1. VM(C) refers to the visual phase of flight after completing an instrument approach to position for landing on a runway not aligned for a straight-in approach.
  2. Any instrument approach (precision or non-precision) can be used, but the descent in the final segment is to the MDA/H for VM(C).
  3. The procedure is considered non-precision, regardless of the type of instrument approach used.
  4. It allows flexibility to land visually after an instrument approach in varied runway configurations.

question: Minimum obstacle clearance at runway end during departure is what?
subject: Regulations
explanation:
The minimum obstacle clearance at the departure end of the runway (DER) is:

  1. Zero feet at the DER.
  2. After the DER, the obstacle clearance increases by 0.8% of the horizontal distance in the direction of flight.
  3. This assumes a maximum track divergence of 15° from the runway alignment.

question: A public transport flight cannot take-off unless which minima are satisfied?
subject: Regulations
explanation:
Aerodrome Operating Minima:

  1. It refers to the cloud ceiling and runway visual range (RVR) required for take-off.
  2. For landing, it includes the decision height or minimum descent height, RVR, and visual reference necessary.
  3. These are the minimum weather conditions under which the aircraft can safely operate at the aerodrome.
  4. The minima ensure that pilots have sufficient visual cues for safe take-off, approach, and landing.

question: During circling, if runway is lost, what must the pilot do?

choices.choice: Turn towards the inner marker for the runway in use, maintaining circling altitude
If you have other visual cues, continue with ground contact

subject: Regulations
explanation:
If visual reference is lost while circling to land from an instrument procedure:

  1. The missed approach for the instrument approach runway must be followed.
  2. The pilot should initiate a climbing turn towards the landing runway.
  3. Upon reaching overhead the aerodrome, the aircraft should be established on the missed approach track.
  4. This ensures a safe transition from circling to the missed approach procedure.

question: Below transition level, where is QNH obtained from?

Ask the met man to forecast the QNH for the route before you take off
Ask the FIS controller for local aerodrome QNHs

explanation:
When flying en route below the transition level, you should ask the Flight Information Service (FIS) controller for local aerodrome QNHs to ensure accurate altitude readings based on the current atmospheric pressure along your route.

question: In ILS, the final approach segment begins at what point?
subject: Regulations
explanation:
For ILS/MLS approaches, the final segment begins at the Final Approach Point (FAP). This point is:

  1. Defined as the location on the localizer centerline (or specified MLS azimuth) where the intermediate approach altitude intercepts the nominal glide path.
  2. This interception can occur at heights between 300 m (1000 ft) and 900 m (3000 ft).
  3. For a typical 3° glide path (300 ft per nautical mile), this would occur between 3 NM and 10 NM from touchdown.

question: A procedure turn is defined as what?
subject: Regulations
explanation:
A procedure turn is a maneuver used during instrument approaches to reverse the aircraft’s direction and establish it on the intermediate or final approach course. It is a standard method of turning the aircraft around when transitioning from the outbound to inbound leg of an approach, ensuring proper alignment with the runway.

question: Who determines OCA/H for instrument approaches?
subject: Regulations
explanation:

question: Circling OCA/H is determined based on what?

For each category of aircraft, and it may be different for each one of them
For all categories of aircraft, and it is the same for all of them

question: A straight-in approach from non-precision is allowed if track differs by how much?
subject: Regulations
explanation:

question: Under what conditions may descent below OCA on VOR approach occur?

choices.choice: When the aircraft has the control tower in sight
When the aircraft is visual contact with the ground and with the runway in sight
When the aircraft is in contact with the ground but not with the runway in sight yet

An aircraft on a straight-in VOR approach may continue its descent below the Obstacle Clearance Altitude (OCA) only:

When the aircraft is in visual contact with the ground and with the runway in sight.

This ensures that the pilot has the necessary visual cues for a safe landing. Simply seeing the ground or control tower is not sufficient; the runway must be in sight to continue descending below the OCA.

question: Entry into holding must follow which ICAO sectors?

question: In ISA, FL150 equals what altitude?
subject: Regulations
explanation:
In the standard atmosphere, Flight Level 150 (FL 150) corresponds to an altitude of 15,000 feet. To convert this to meters, you can use the conversion factor where 1 foot = 0.3048 meters.

So:

15,000 feet×0.3048=4,572 meters

Rounding this to the nearest option, FL 150 is equivalent to approximately 4,550 meters.

subject: Regulations
explanation:
1. When flying en route below the transition altitude, the aircraft’s vertical position is reported as altitude, with the QNH set on the altimeter.
  2. Once outside the vicinity of the departure aerodrome, the QNH from a closer aerodrome will need to be obtained and set.
  3. This ensures that the altitude remains accurate with respect to mean sea level (MSL), improving terrain clearance and aircraft separation as the flight progresses.

question: With QNH set, a serviceable altimeter should read what on the ground?

choices.choice: The height of the aeroplane above the datum
The elevation of the position of the aeroplane plus the height of the altimeter static vent
The altitude of the aeroplane above the datum

subject: Regulations
explanation:
When the QNH is set on the altimeter subscale, the altimeter will read the aerodrome elevation when the aircraft is at that aerodrome’s elevation (at sea level).

question: Define a circling approach.

choices.choice: A flight manoeuvre to be performed only under radar vectoring
A visual flight manoeuvre keeping the runway in sight

subject: Regulations
explanation:
1. A circling approach is a visual maneuver requiring constant sight of the runway environment while at MDA/H.
  2. Each circling situation varies due to factors like runway layout, final approach track, wind, and weather conditions.
  3. There is no single procedure applicable to all circling approaches; pilots must adapt to each scenario.
  4. Initial visual contact assumes that runway markings, lights, and approach lighting will remain visible throughout the approach.

question: What does MEHT stand for?
subject: Regulations
explanation:
Minimum Eye Height (MEHT)

question: ILS glide slope is normally intercepted between what altitudes?
subject: Regulations
explanation:
The ILS (Instrument Landing System) glide path is typically intercepted between 3 and 10 NM from the runway threshold. This range allows for sufficient time and altitude for pilots to establish on the glide path and make the necessary adjustments for a safe landing.

question: What main factor dictates instrument departure design?
subject: Regulations
explanation:
• Instrument departure procedures assume that all engines are operating normally.
  • The design of these procedures is primarily dictated by the terrain surrounding the aerodrome.
  • Procedures may also be tailored to accommodate ATC requirements, including adjacent ATS routes.
  • Considerations include restricted, prohibited, or danger areas, as well as the proximity of other aerodromes.

question: The circling maneuver after instrument approach to align with runway is called what?
subject: Regulations
explanation:
Visual Manoeuvring (Circling) (VM(C)) refers to the visual phase of flight following the completion of an instrument approach. It is used to position the aircraft for landing on a runway that is not aligned for a straight-in approach. Any instrument procedure (precision or non-precision) can be used, but the descent in the final segment will be made to the Minimum Descent Altitude/Height (MDA/H) for VM(C). This phase allows the pilot to visually maneuver the aircraft for landing.

question: For precision approach OCA, obstacle height is referenced to what?

choices.choice: highest obstacle within 25 nm of aerodrome

subject: Regulations
explanation:
When determining the Obstacle Clearance Altitude (OCA) for a precision approach, obstacle height is referenced to Mean Sea Level (MSL).

\n

This ensures that the obstacle clearance is calculated based on the actual altitude above sea level, which provides a standard reference for terrain and obstacles around the aerodrome.

question: With Mode C transponder, what must pilot do?
subject: Regulations
explanation:
“Unless otherwise directed by ATC”

\n

When an aircraft carries a serviceable Mode C transponder, it should be operated continuously, but ATC can issue instructions to change or turn off the transponder if needed.

question: On receiving TA, pilots must respond how?

choices.choice: Respond immediately by following the TA as indicated
Not manoeuvre their aircraft in response to traffic advisories (TAs) only
Notify the appropriate ATC unit of the TA

subject: Regulations
explanation:
Pilots should not take evasive action based solely on a Traffic Advisory (TA). They should only maneuver if they receive a Resolution Advisory (RA) from the onboard traffic collision avoidance system (TCAS) or if instructed by ATC. However, they should maintain awareness and be prepared to act if an RA follows the TA.

question: Entering SSR airspace from non-SSR, what squawk should be set?
subject: Regulations
explanation:
• Mode A code 2000 is used by aircraft entering an area where radar service is available.
  • It indicates that the aircraft will be requesting radar service upon entry.
  • This code is typically used by aircraft transitioning from an Oceanic control area into a domestic Flight Information Region (FIR).

question: With single SSR control box, how should squawk change be done?

choices.choice: Squawk 'standby', then change the code; then squawk 'normal'.
Squawk 'off', then change the code; then Squawk 'normal'.
Only change one digit at a time

subject: Regulations
explanation:
• Set the option switch to standby (STBY) before selecting or changing the code.
  • Select the new transponder code while in standby mode.
  • Once the new code is selected, reset the option switch to ON or ALT

question: MSA around nav aid is valid for what distance?
subject: Regulations
explanation:
The Minimum Sector Altitude (MSA) is the lowest altitude which may be used which will provide a minimum clearance of 300 m (1 000 ft) above all objects located in the area contained within a sector of a circle of 46 km (25 NM) radius centred on a radio aid to navigation.

question: Define a “radial.”

choices.choice: A magnetic bearing to or from a VOR station, depending on whether the aircraft is inbound or outbound to or from the VOR
A magnetic bearing to a VOR station
A magnetic bearing extending from a VOR station

subject: Regulations
explanation:
VOR navigation uses a combination of ground-based stations and onboard devices. The ground stations transmit signals in a pattern called radials, which are 360 distinct magnetic bearings extending out from the station.

question: OCH for precision approach is defined how?

choices.choice: The lowest height above mean sea level of the relevant runway used in establishing
The lowest altitude above the aerodrome elevation used in establishing compliance with appropriate obstacle clearance requirements
The lowest height above the elevation of the relevant runway threshold, at which a missed approach must be initiated to ensure compliance with the appropriate obstacle clearance criteria

subject: Regulations
explanation:
The Obstacle Clearance Height (OCH) for a precision approach is defined as:

  1. The height above the elevation of the runway threshold.
  2. It ensures obstacle clearance for the aircraft during the final stages of the approach and in the event of a missed approach.
  3. OCH is associated with the Decision Height (DH), where a decision to land or execute a missed approach must be made.
  4. It accounts for obstacles in the approach and missed approach paths, providing a safe margin during descent and go-around procedures.

question: Approach categories are based on what aircraft characteristic?

choices.choice: 1.3 times the stalling speed in clean configuration at minimum certified landing mass
1.3 times the stalling speed in the landing configuration at minimum certified landing mass
1.3 times the stalling speed in the landing configuration at maximum certified landing mass

subject: Regulations
explanation:
1.3 times the stalling speed in the landing configuration at maximum certified landing mass.

\n

This speed is used to assign aircraft into different approach categories (A, B, C, D, E) to determine appropriate circling radii and approach procedures.

question: If visual contact is lost while circling, what must pilot do initially?
subject: Regulations
explanation:
• If visual reference is lost while circling to land, the missed approach for the instrument approach runway must be followed.
  • The pilot should initiate a climbing turn towards the landing runway.
  • Once overhead the aerodrome, the aircraft should be established on the specified missed approach track.
  • This ensures a safe transition from circling to the missed approach procedure.

question: Who sets aerodrome operational minima?

choices.choice: The appropriate authority of the State of the aircraft operator
The appropriate authority of the State of the aerodrome

subject: Regulations
explanation:
Aerodrome Operational Minima (AOM) are calculated by the operator using information and guidelines provided by the national aviation authority of the operator’s state.

question: Holding pattern timing above FL140 is how long outbound?
subject: Regulations
explanation:
• Time/Distance Outbound:
    • At or below 4,250 m (14,000 ft): Outbound heading time should not exceed one minute.
    • Above 4,250 m (14,000 ft): Outbound heading time should not exceed one and one-half minutes.
  • When DME (Distance Measuring Equipment) is available, the outbound leg length can be specified in distance rather than time.

question: At a non-standard holding fix, turns should be made in which direction?
subject: Regulations
explanation:
When asked to hold on a non-standard holding fix (e.g., en route), the turns are typically made to the left unless specified otherwise by ATC.

\n

In standard holding patterns, turns are to the right, but in non-standard holds, turns are often to the left unless directed.

\n

question: In standard holding, turns are in which direction?

choices.choice: In a direction depending on the wind direction

subject: Regulations
explanation:
A standard holding pattern involves right (starboard) turns around the holding fix. This means that all turns made in the pattern are to the right unless specified otherwise by air traffic control or specific procedures.

question: What is the purpose of an EAT?

choices.choice: When an aircraft is instructed to hold
Once an aircraft has been holding for 20 minutes

subject: Regulations
explanation:
Expected Approach Time (EAT): When an aircraft enters a stack, the controlling ATCO will pass an EAT, which must be acknowledged by the pilot.

\n

Stacking: stacking refers to the holding pattern procedure where multiple aircraft are positioned at different altitudes, one above the other, in a vertical “stack”.

question: At 5 nm from holding area, what obstacle clearance is guaranteed?
subject: Regulations
explanation:
Surrounding the holding area a buffer zone, 5 NM wide, is established within which decreasing MOC is applied from full MOC at the boundary with the holding area, to zero at the extremity.

\n

MOC: Minimum Obstacle Clearance

question: Standard holding below 14,000 ft requires what pattern?
subject: Regulations
explanation:
In standard holding patterns, turns are to the right, but in non-standard holds, turns are often to the left unless directed.

  • Time/Distance Outbound:
    • At or below 4,250 m (14,000 ft): Outbound heading time should not exceed one minute.
    • Above 4,250 m (14,000 ft): Outbound heading time should not exceed one and one-half minutes.

question: All holding turns are to be made at what speed/angle?

choices.choice: Rate of 3°/sec or at a bank angle of 25°, which ever requires the lesser bank
Rate of 3°/sec or at a bank angle of 20°, which ever requires the lesser bank

subject: Regulations
explanation:
• All turns are to be made at an angle of bank of 25° or at a rate of 3° per second (rate 1), whichever requires the lesser bank.
  • All the procedures depict tracks.
  • Pilots should attempt to maintain the track by making allowance for known wind.
  • Wind correction should be applied both to heading and timing.
  • Corrections are needed during entry and while flying the holding pattern.

question: Required bank angle in holding pattern is how many degrees?
subject: Regulations
explanation: • All turns are to be made at an angle of bank of 25° or at a rate of 3° per second (rate 1), whichever requires the lesser bank.

question: Sector entry flexibility extends how many degrees each side?
subject: Regulations
explanation:
• Three methods exist for joining a holding pattern based on the aircraft’s heading as it approaches the holding fix.
  • These methods are determined by three defined sectors around the holding fix.
  • Each sector has its specific joining procedure based on the approach heading.
  • A 5° flexibility area exists between each sector boundary.
  • Within this flexibility area, the pilot can choose the applicable joining procedure.
